info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued February 13 at 3:19AM PST by NWS Reno
info.description: ...A Brief Return to Winter Monday Night into Tuesday Morning... After another dry and warm day today, a fast moving slider-type low pressure system and cold front will move quickly across eastern California and the Great Basin late Monday into Tuesday. This will bring an increase in winds Monday afternoon, and colder conditions with a short period of rain and snow Monday evening through early Tuesday. * Winds: Southwest to west winds will increase Monday afternoon and evening with gusts 35 to 45 mph. Wind prone areas along US-395 between Susanville and Gardnerville may gust up to 55 mph, with Sierra ridge gusts approaching 100 mph. * Rain/Snow: A band of rain and snow will move southward from Monday evening through late night. Accumulations of 1-3 inches are possible for the Tahoe basin northward into eastern Sierra and Plumas counties, with up to an inch for foothills in far western Nevada. For lower elevations of western Nevada, rain will likely end as a brief period of snow, with snow amounts ranging from a dusting to one half inch. * Temperatures: Sharply colder temperatures near or below freezing will arrive late Monday night into Tuesday. While the snow is expected to end prior to the Tuesday morning commute, slick patches could remain, especially on roads above 5000 feet and overpasses. Slow down and allow extra travel time for Tuesday morning.
